discourse_list.title: Johnson v. Maker Foundation Litigation Continues

content.content: Disclaimer – This post is meant to be informational and for discussion. You should discuss any legal questions you have about the MakerDAO ecosystem or any other legal issues with your counsel. I had not seen any other posts on the matter and thought that other community members might also be curious to know more on the status of the “Black Thursday” litigation against the Maker Foundation and other entities. Looking through the public docket, there were two recent points of interest that I wanted to flag for the community. First , in June of this year, plaintiffs moved to re-open the US district court (federal-level trial court) case, which had been stayed pending arbitration. The motion was based on the arbitration panel’s May 16th ruling:     AAA:  The Panel finds that the Claimant’s claims fall outside the scope of the 2018 Terms of Service because those claims relate to Claimant’s use of services under a subsequent digital platform that was governed by the 2019 Terms of Service. Therefore, this matter is not arbitrable under the 2018 Terms of Service.   https://ipfs.io/ipfs/Qmf5K8emF7qxSZbAGZuwK18m8uKerf4b6dAFm97dq7g8ud?filename=Maker%20re-opened%20case.pdf Second , Plaintiffs received permission to file a Second Amended Complaint (draft here). A few notes on that. The Dai Foundation has been dropped from the complaint. The remaining named defendants are Maker Ecosystem Growth Holdings, Inc. n/k/a Metronym, Inc. and Maker Ecosystem Growth Foundation. Paragraphs 5 and 6 further describe the defendants:     Complaint:  The Maker Ecosystem Growth Holdings, Inc. (“Maker Growth”) is a foreign company (organized and operating under the laws of the Cayman Islands), with its primary place of business in California. On information and belief, Maker Growth has recently renamed itself as, Metronym, Inc. (“Metronym”). Metronym has stepped into the shoes of Maker Growth and assumed its business assets and liabilities. Metronym, like Maker Growth is a foreign company (organized and operating under the laws of the Cayman Islands). For purposes of this Complaint, Maker Ecosystem Growth Holdings, Inc. is referred to as Metronym or Maker Growth. But in each instance, all references are to the current, active corporate entity previously known and operated as Maker Ecosystem Growth Holdings, Inc. Maker Ecosystem Growth Foundation is a foreign company (organized and operating under the laws of the Cayman Islands), with its primary place of business in California. On information and belief, Maker Ecosystem Growth Foundation is an affiliate of Maker Growth and overlaps in the management, operation, and development of the Maker Protocol (defined below) and its related ecosystem. On information and belief, Maker Ecosystem Growth Foundation has recently dissolved.   Plaintiff is seeking class certification to represent all vault holders who lost money. The causes of action remain the same as the initial complaint, and first amended complaint, i.e., Negligence, Intentional Misrepresentation, and Negligent Misrepresentation. Again, I want to stress that I’m not offering any advice or assessment of the strength of the complaint or outcomes. I will remind anyone reading these that anyone can file a complaint, and the allegations aren’t necessarily supported with any evidence (though lawyers can get in trouble if they make representations they know are false). This will be an interesting case to watch. Long term, it could set some precedent for Foundation liability for DAO actions, successor liability, and potentially the scope of permissible equitable relief, depending on the scope of the defendants token holdings. Edit: Apparently I fail at IPFS, so here are scribd links:   Scribd    ECF 63 - Unopposed Motion to Reopen Case | PDF | Arbitration | Plaintiff Unopposed motion to reopen case in Johnson v Maker Foundation et al.         Scribd    ECF 67-1 Proposed Second Amended Complaint | PDF | Class Action |... Proposed SAC in Johnson v Maker Foundation et al.         Scribd    ECF 68 - Order Granting Motion to Amend | PDF | Complaint | United States Law Order granting motion to amend complaint in Johnson v Maker Foundation et al.

I’m really not caught up on this matter but I wonder what impact, if any, the coinebase arbitration clause invalidation issue might have especially since these are all in the 9th circuit. Coinbase's Motion To Stay Litigation Denied By Supreme Court Not sure if this case is headed back to arbitration based upon some other agreement but the issue as to the enforceability of certain clauses in the terms and conditions is a big deal.
